results.headline: Trading Wig and Floppy Dress for a Badge

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alex Cross

results.summary_short: Tyler Perry plays the title character in “Alex Cross,” based on a James Patterson novel.

results.headline: It’s Not About the Destination, but About the Dizzying Ride

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Holy Motors

results.summary_short: In “Holy Motors,” the French filmmaker Leos Carax opens the door to a world full of laughter, horror and rapture, reminding you just how drearily conventional many movies are.

results.headline: Glories of Capitalism, With Gas at $40 a Gallon
results.display_title: Atlas Shrugged: Part II -- The Strike

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Atlas Shrugged: Part II -- The Strike

results.summary_short: “Atlas Shrugged: Part II” is like “Part I” in that it was made for true believers of Ayn Rand and her novel “Atlas Shrugged.”

results.headline: What’s a Gang to Do? Join the Other Crooks to Snare a Jewel

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Thieves

results.summary_short: New frontiers in burglary: rival gangs join forces in this tale from Dong-hoon Choi.

results.headline: A Fugitive’s Identity Theft Has a Highly Personal Twist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Big Picture

results.summary_short: “The Big Picture” is a French thriller about a husband who fakes his death after accidentally killing his wife’s lover, then assumes the lover’s identity.

results.headline: A Relationship’s Glue Is Made of Alcohol

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Smashed

results.summary_short: “Smashed,” directed by James Ponsoldt, finds Mary Elizabeth Winstead as a schoolteacher whose drinking spins out of control.

results.headline: Two Families Become One in World War II

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Simon and the Oaks

results.summary_short: In “Simon and the Oaks,” directed by Lisa Ohlin, two boys — one working-class, one wealthy and Jewish — find something they need in each other.

results.headline: Small Pleasures, Scattered Amid Struggles

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Middle of Nowhere

results.summary_short: “Middle of Nowhere” is a plaintive, slow-boiling, quietly soul-stirring drama about a woman coming into her own.

results.headline: Outwitting the Ayatollah With Hollywood’s Help

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Argo

results.summary_short: “Argo” is a doozy of a story and so borderline ridiculous that it sounds like something that could have been cooked up only by Hollywood.

results.headline: No, He Really Doesn’t Want to Be on YouTube

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 3,2,1...Frankie Go Boom

results.summary_short: In “3, 2, 1 ... Frankie Go Boom,” directed and written by Jordan Roberts, a man (Chris O’Dowd) can’t resist making embarrassing films about his brother (Charlie Hunnam).

results.headline: If Only It Were All About the Buttons

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The War of the Buttons

results.summary_short: Christophe Barratier sets the telling of this story (written in 1912) in occupied France in the spring of 1944, contrasting the button war with the deadly serious adult one.

results.headline: A Tough Team Out to Save a Journalist in Peril

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Special Forces

results.summary_short: The French president, outraged over the kidnapping of a reporter writing about the Taliban, sends in elite commandos on a rescue mission.

results.headline: At the Scene of the Crime

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sinister

results.summary_short: Ethan Hawke is a true-crime writer moving his family into the house of the slaughtered family he is investigating for a book.

results.headline: His Ink Has Dried Up, but Look at All the Blood

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Seven Psychopaths

results.summary_short: “Seven Psychopaths,” written and directed by Martin McDonagh, finds a writer in trouble in Los Angeles.

results.headline: The Images That Bind a Director and His Son

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Photographic Memory

results.summary_short: Ross McElwee’s new documentary concerns images of the past, including those of his son, and how the context and his own perceptions may have changed over time.

results.headline: A Smug Writer Meets His Match

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Madrid, 1987

results.summary_short: José Sacristán plays a dismissive journalist in “Madrid, 1987” who opens up to a young woman who he hopes to seduce.

results.headline: A Veteran and a Neighbor Boy, Both Troubled

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Least Among Saints

results.summary_short: In “Least Among Saints,” a former Marine has hard time being back home, and a 10-year-old has a hard time staying in his.

results.headline: Fighting, Literally, to Save a School Program

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Here Comes the Boom

results.summary_short: In “Here Comes the Boom,” Kevin James plays a teacher determined to save his high school’s music program by earning money in mixed martial arts bouts.

results.headline: Making a Baby in a Shockingly Usual  Way

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gayby

results.summary_short: A straight woman who wants a child asks her gay friend to help out in “Gayby.”

results.headline: In Rehab, Surrounded by Older Men

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Excuse Me for Living

results.summary_short: Tom Pelphrey plays a man with a taste for various debaucheries who ends up in treatment.
